citation.article-title: Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. pectinolytica subsp. nov., a new pectinase-positive subspecies isolated from a heavily polluted river.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. pectinolytica subsp. nov.

Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. pectinolytica (pec'tin.o.ly.ti.ca. Gr. adj. pekticos congealing or hardening; M.L. n. pectinum pectin; Gr. adj. lytos loosening; M.L. fem adj. lytica loosening or dissolving; M.L. adj. pectinolytica pectin-dissolving, named after its ability to degrade polypectate, an unusual characteristic for the Aeromonas species)
Gram-negative straight non-motile rods, occurring singly, in pairs or short chains.
Chemoorganotrophic with both oxidative and fermentative metabolism, cytochrome oxidase and catalase-positive, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and resistant to vibriostatic agent O/129.
Colonies develop within 24 h at 35 °C on standard media and a brown diffusible pigment is formed.
Acid is produced from D-glucose (with gas), cellobiose, L-arabinose, D-sorbitol, mannitol, lactose, sucrose and glycerol, but not from L-rhamnose.
Polypectate, DNA and gelatin are degraded.
Neither aesculin nor urea are hydrolysed.
Citrate and urocanic acid are used.
Other properties as described in Table 1.
Isolated from the water of a polluted river, the Matanza river, Buenos Aires, Argentina.
